Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project has four key focus areas which are designed to
provide opportunities for student learning, retention and success. The Outreach component
targets the K-12 system to foster science exploration and success with the ultimate goal of
increasing the number of students choosing STEM science careers. At the college level, the
project will increase enrollment of STEM science majors through the development of new
courses and programs. For retention of STEM students, the project will foster increased
opportunities for student success. To increase completion/transfer/four year graduation
rates, TMCC will initiate partnerships with four year schools to upgrade its curricula, initiate joint
research and aid students in developing familiarity with four year schools.

The project will conduct an in-depth review and revision of the existing
TMCC science courses. This effort meets two critical needs: enhancing student learning by
providing more hands-on activities and ensuring the curricula is consistent with the standards at
four year schools. In the latter area, the project will foster partnerships between the college and
four year colleges. These partnerships are expected to bridge the rural isolation experienced by
the TMCC faculty and provide four year school familiarity to students prior to transfer.
As this project is the demonstration of how involvement in learning impacts student
achievement and career choices, it is applicable not only in STEM subjects but across the
curriculum. The current literature suggests student learning is heavily impacted by how
engaged the student is in the learning process. Using a results driven approach, the project will
identify what enhancements positively impact student learning not only at the college level, but
across the continuum of education. The results of this project can be replicated not only at the
college level but in K-12 Native American programs.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Title:  TMCC Science Enhancement

            The project included outreach to the K-12 schools to stimulate science exploration and success, increased enrollment of STEM majors through new majors, increased retention through additional opportunities for student success, and higher completion/transfer rates. The project provided opportunities for students to participate in research both at TMCC and through partnerships with four-year colleges/universities. TMCC, with four-year partners, reviewed and revised TMCC science curricula for parity with 4 year programs.

1. STEM summer camps for middle school and high school students and academic year Sunday Academies for high school students with documented increases in science learning during the camps.

2. Middle and high school students that later attended TMCC had, on average, a 30.8% higher GPA than that of the general TMCC student population. 

3. Conducted a science fair each year for the local schools.

4. Provided college students as mentors to aid local school children with science fair projects.

5. Developed and taught a scientific research methods course.

6. Developed and implemented a science placement test for incoming TMCC freshmen to identify students needing developmental science.

7. Developed and taught a developmental science survey course.

8. Developed and implemented a series of outdoor labs covering local flora, fauna and ecosystems. 

9. Designed and implemented an environmental science degree.

10. Increased yearly enrollment in STEM courses at TMCC by up to 46%.

11. Increased the percentage of students earning a 3.0 GPA or better in TMCC science coursework.  The increase was as much as 68%.

12. Increased the yearly number of Associate of Science degree recipients at TMCC by 55%. 

13. Fostered research collaboration with four-year universities to the extent that now over 75% of current TMCC research projects involve collaboration with four-year universities. 

14. Students involved in research graduated at a higher rate than the general TMCC student population. 

15. Increased the TMCC graduation rate of science majors.

16. Facilitated a structured review, conducted by science faculty from the Univ. of North Dakota, of the TMCC life science, physical science and earth science courses and curricula.

17. A research project discovered a leech from a species last reported in 1874 which will be added to the Smithsonian Institute collection.

18. Conducted student research projects on plant succession, leech biology, turtle biology, stream ecology and mosquito ecology.

19. The project director was first author on a peer-reviewed publication of a portion of the research conducted by this program: Hanson, S. M., Y. Hou and M. D. Hellwig. 2012. Recharging Centers for Disease Control light trap batteries with solar panels. Journal of Applied Science and Technology.

20. A short article about a portion of the research conducted by this program in a journal without peer review:  Hanson, S. 2013. Mosquito trapping goes solar at TMCC. Tribal College Journal. 24(3) 32. 

21. A short article about a portion of the research conducted by this program in a journal without peer review:  Hanson, S. 2013. TMCC leeches sent to Smithsonian. Tribal College Journal. 24(3) 47 and 48.  

 


Last Modified: 12/24/2014
Modified by: Scott M Hanson
